bboxes.raw_text:
ST. LOUIS Jimmy Hill, St.
Louis Cardinal halfback, named
to the All-Pro team, filed a 2
million dollar suit against Time,
Inc, and the Pierce News Agency.


Hiss bases his suit on a Nov.ll,
1868 article inSports Illustrated,
distributed by the agency, which
accused the halfback of injuring
willfully Green Bay Packer quar-
terback Bart Starr.


Jack Monterey, Hills attorney
said the story suggested that his
client was playing "diry foot
BALL.

WASHINGTON-NA 55th
annual convention opened June
d marking the third time the
ass ociation has held it's yearly
confab In Washington.


approximately 1000 delegates
representing 1850 chapters will
attend. Membership totals have
been set at 100000.


Roy Wilkins, executive secre-
tary since 1855, and the assistant
secretary since 1881, will re-
ceive the 10th Spingarn Medal.


The gold award is presented
to the Negro American for out
standing achievement for advanc-
ing the race and the American
people.

NAACP HOLDS
ANNUAL MEET
AT WASHINGTON

Mrs. Edith Easter. 20, has been
chosen by Judge R. C. Stanford,
Jr., to be his court clerk on
Aug. l.. when his present clerk
is promoted.


Mrs. Easter will be the first
Negro to receive a permanent
assignment as a division clerk
in Maricopa County Superior
Court.


She graduated from Phoenix
Technical School in 1855 and
during her last semester parti-
cipated in on the job training as
stenographer with the county
health department.


She was employed with the
health department and the state
education department before
being assigned as a deputy clerk
in the county court system.


Mrs. Easter, her husband,
Floyd and their three children
live at 1892 W. Sells Drive.

Mrs. Easter
Named Permanent
Court Clerk

Charles N. Roman has an
nounced his candidacy for re-
election as Maricopa County
Attorney in the Democratic pri-
mary, seeking his third term.


Earlier this month Roman was
cited county attorney of the
year" by the Arizona County
Attorneys and Sheriffs Associa-
ton for his "ceaseless interest"
in the areas of law enforcement
and crime prevention.

LOS ANC ELES- The city coun-
cirs joint committee urged the
formation of a city human rela-
lions group in an effort to relieve
tensions between the police force
and the Negro citizens.


Police Chief William H. Par
ker demonstrated his unwilling
ness to criticism and he stalked
out of the meeting after witness
said two officers had mistreated
him.


He was grim as DR.. James L.
Jones. Negro psychiatrist, told
of rough treatment when he was
arrested without any cause while
Sitting in his parked car in Holly
wood.

Hum on Relations
Com mittee Sought
in |. A.

His campaign slogan, he said,
will be: dedicated to justice
for all society,""


individual rights are impor-
tant and must be protected" Ro-
nan explained, "but so must the
rights of society as whole. Jus
tice does not belong exclusively
to criminals. Society is also en-
titled to protection. And by So
ciety, | mean all law-abiding
citizens.'

MIR. and Mrs. Edward Banks,
publishers and editors of The
Arizona Tribune are attending the
National Newspaper Publishers
ASS ociation annual convention in

San Francisco, June 1927.


The Arizona Tribune office will
be closed this weekend.


Telephone Lonnie Billops
254-292l for photos.

Personal aid is given plus smile by Leroy Hughes assistant
F. w. Woolwor located the Lake
shopping plaza Chicago The is his wife, Constance
and she is trying to choose rolling pin.


The couple the Woolwort Cary Ind where Leroy
worked in afternoons part dsrbuve education program
Emerson high school, completing DE program
companys management training program


His wife the rolling cooking only.

WELCOME TO THE ELKS PACIFIC
STATES ASSOCIATION CONVENTION


THE ARIZONA TRIBUNE WISHES Vol


GRAND TIME IN OUR GREAT CITY

Vacation Bible School held for than hundred young
pupils First Institutional Baptist Church. l4l E. Jefferson.
Top photo left shows the teaching staff which included
jeanne Williams Ouda Brown Ruth Battle Matte Devne.
Standing Mines Billie Steele Edith Radord Vernoa HARRISON
Kathryn Nash and Rosa Edwards.
